Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Theoretical-Computational Network for Extracting Astrophysics and Fundamental Physics from Multi-Messenger Observations of Compact Objects
Award.AbstractNarration: This project will create a Theoretical and Computational Astrophysics Network with major nodes at the California Institute of Technology, Syracuse University, Cornell University, and the University of Washington to advance the theory of merging compact-object binaries and stellar collapse. Gravitational waves from these types of events are expected to be detected by the Advanced Laser Interferometer Gravitational Wave Observatory in coming years. The network team's goals are to develop the theoretical and computational tools needed to extract the equation of state of dense nuclear matter from gravitational wave and electromagnetic observations, and to determine the impact of compact-object mergers on the synthesis of light and heavy elements. The team will combine its expertise in numerical relativity, nuclear astrophysics, and gravitational wave detection to (1) develop an open-source, next-generation relativistic astrophysics computation framework; (2) improve the theoretical understanding of the nuclear equation of state and compute a large ensemble of equations of state for different temperatures and compositions; (3) improve the computational treatment of nuclear reactions in merger and collapse simulations; and (4) develop parameter estimation techniques to extract information on the equation of state from multi-messenger observations. The network will contribute to scientific workforce development through the involvement of graduate students and postdocs, who will receive cross-disciplinary training in modeling, microphysics, and multi-messenger observations. Outreach videos with visualizations and interviews with project scientists will be disseminated via YouTube to enhance public understanding.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This collaborative project involved researchers of California Institute of Technology, Cornell University, Syracuse University, and the University of Washington. Its central objective was to develop new theoretical and computational tools and methodologies that are needed for understanding LIGO gravitational wave observations.

LIGO has very recently made spectacular discoveries -- the first direct observation of two black holes colliding and the first observation of a merger of two neutron stars, causing a gamma-ray burst. With this, LIGO has unequivocally established that "Einstein was right," that gravitational waves are a reality. This is already exciting and groundbreaking -- and LIGO's discoveries led to the 2017 Nobel Prize in Physics, awarded to Weiss, Thorne, and Barish.

However, there is much more to be learned from current and future gravitational wave observations. On the one hand, we can learn about detailed astrophysics of the wave-generating phenomena. We get additional information from astronomical observatories and also from observations of neutrinos (tiny elementary particles) that are generated when two neutron stars collide or when a star goes supernova. Combining multiple of these "messengers" is called "multi-messenger astronomy." On the other hand, there is hope to learn fundamental physics from these observations. For example, we could learn about the uncertain nuclear force that holds together atomic nuclei and that prevents neutron stars (temporarily or permanently) from collapsing to black holes.

There is, however, a central problem to all this: In order to interpret and understand these spectacular observations, and to learn astrophysics and fundamental physics, detailed, reliable, and reproducible theoretical predictions are needed. Because the physics of cosmic phenomena is so complex, predictions can be obtained only by performing computational simulations on the nation's largest supercomputers. Once the predictions are obtained, clever strategies are needed to combine them and contrast them with observations to learn the desired astrophysics or fundamental physics.

The project team developed a next-generation simulation code called SpECTRE. This code uses next-generation technology approaches to work not only on the current fastest supercomputers, but also on future computers that will be a factor of 1000 or more faster. SpECTRE is available as "open source", this means everybody can download it and try it out. It runs on anything from a laptop computer to the nation's largest supercomputers.

In addition to SpECTRE, the team also developed key physics inputs for simulations. For example, a new an open framework that lets one generate descriptions of neutron star matter for a given set of input parameters for the nuclear force. This allows researchers to perform so-called "sensitivity studies," where changes in results under the controlled variation of input parameters are studied.

The team also developed a new code (also open source) to study the production of heavy elements, including precious metals (gold, platinum, etc.) in neutron star collisions and stellar explosions. This new code was written by one of the graduate student team members and is called SkyNet.

Finally, the team worked with the LIGO scientific collaboration experts on developing data analysis approaches to learn astrophysics and fundamental physics. It developed a new approach for rapidly predicting gravitational wave signals from binary mergers without the need of full supercomputer simulations. Instead, this method uses a catalog of previously simulated gravitational wave signals and generates a "reduced-order" version of it that can be used as a surrogate (i.e. a replacement) for the full simulation. The team showed that this works extremely well for two black holes -- the newly developed methods manages to predict a black hole binary gravitational wave within 50 milliseconds (0.05 seconds) whereas a full simulation would require months to run on a supercomputer.

The project involved three graduate students at Caltech that were supported to carry out their PhD research. They graduated in the final year of the project. Moreover, multiple postdoctoral scholars were involved, trained, and provided with mentoring. Results were published in tens of scientific research papers, contributed and invited lectures at conferences and university departments, and to the broader public via the team's YouTube channel: https://youtube.com/SXSCollaboration .
